data.title: Backspin: Black Moon — Enta Da Stage (1993)
data.meta_description: The hawk is a particular brand of cold that arrives off a near-frozen Atlantic Ocean via whipping winds. It settles deep into the concrete and steel of North Eastern seaboard cities. When the hawk is…
data.text:
If you’re intimately familiar with the piercing chill of “the hawk,” Black Moon makes music for you.

The hawk is a particular brand of cold that arrives off a near-frozen Atlantic Ocean via whipping winds. It settles deep into the concrete and steel of North Eastern seaboard cities. When the hawk is out, you’ll see city dwellers buried beneath layers of fabric, chins tucked low, coats pulled tight. They hustle to train stations and bus stops en route to whatever adventures the night has to offer that are worth braving the hawk’s needle-like talons.

1993 saw hip-hop spiced with greater stylistic variety than ever before. Yet, neither the slinky synths of Southern Cali’s G-funk explosion nor the deep fried soul of the emerging southern movement provided sufficient score to a hawk infested train ride, bodega run, or front stoop blunt session. In October of ’93, just as the hawk was spreading his wings, Black Moon entered the stage right on time.

Lead single “Who Got Da Props?” landed like the first 40 degree day of autumn to acclimate the system for the coming chill. Built atop a sinister rhythm guitar and keys culled from Ronnie Laws’ “Tidal Wave,” the jazzy jaunt felt right at home among the Native Tongue and Hieroglyphics platters with which it shared mix…
